content.intro:
A thriving centre for art, design, and music, the German capital will keep surprising you with its madness and beauty.

Germany's capital and largest city, Berlin has 3.7 million inhabitants. From 1961 to 1989, the city was divided in two by the Berlin Wall, and it was not until 1990 that it again became the nation's capital. From monuments, damaged walls, and Soviet-era buildings, remnants from the past surround you . Despite its ever-present history, the city is one of the youngest in Europe, strongly looking towards the future. It's bustling day and night with partying, dancing, bicycling, open-air museums, and dance halls down at the waterfront. For artists and creators, Berlin now is like the New York of the 1960s, a city where everything is possible… and a little crazy.
Berlin is full of history, and its monuments remind you of it on every street corner. The Reichstag, Museum Island, and the Holocaust Memorial are essential stops during your journey in the city. Take advantage of your stay to discover an abandoned airport transformed into family park, climb to the top of the TV tower that dominates the city, find out about the remains of the Wall, decorated by artists from around the world, sail on the Spree river or visit an old train station transformed into a museum of contemporary art.
You can also grab a takeaway currywurst, Berlin's favourite sausage, test the Korean barbecue in one of the most cosmopolitan addresses in the city, or book a table at Cookies Cream, the vegetarian restaurant known around the world. In Berlin, you can sleep in a former embassy overlooking the zoo, in a slightly quirky arty hotel with basketball hoops in the lobby, or rent a stylish apartment in the heart of the city. Here, everything is different, ecstatically underground and offbeat, yet always so vibrant.

map.mapTitle: Our selection of must-see places in and around Berlin

seoData.seoTitle: Berlin, a passionately trendy city - Berlin Travel Guide
seoData.seoDescription: A thriving centre for art, design, and music, the German capital will keep surprising you with its madness and beauty.

localCalendar.title: FESTIVALS, HOLIDAYS AND OTHER ANNUAL EVENTS IN Berlin

content.title: Coda Dessert Dining's gastronomic delicacies

introduction.small: Food lovers always dreamt of a pastry-only meal, and Coda made it a reality. This starred dessert restaurant in Berlin reveals a creative take in which sugar is not an issue.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Coda Dessert Dining's gastronomic delicacies

paragraphs.text:
Also called “Little Istanbul”, the cosmopolitan and lively Neukölln district is known to shelter many of Berlin's most rousing addresses. With Coda, it remains true to that fact, as this atypical restaurant is entirely devoted to dessert serving. In the kitchen, pastry chef René Frank created a menu of delicacies, sometimes up to seven courses. The house mixologist will pair each dish with creation cocktails. Forget what you think you know about desserts, as eating at Coda Dessert Dining is neither sickly-sweet nor bad for the health, all desserts being sugar-free, and usually quite low in calories. The procession of flavours organized by René Frank is based on the original taste of fruits and vegetables. For instance, the eggplant-based dessert adds pecan nut, apple and balsamic vinegar, and the rhubarb one is mixed with tofu and tarragon. This melting pot is so engaging that Coda was even awarded a Michelin star for its innovative cuisine and exceptional savoir-faire.

Coda Dessert Dining
Friedelstraße 47
12047 Berlin

+49 (0)30 914 963 96

coda-berlin.com/en/

Menu: from 54 EUR

content.title: Food and beer pairing at BRLO Brwhouse

introduction.small: On the outskirts of Gleisdreieck Park, BRLO Brwhouse is a 3-in-1 microbrewery, bar and restaurant.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Food and beer pairing at BRLO Brwhouse

paragraphs.text:
BRLO Brwhouse is already well-known among Berliners. Famous for its crafted beers, handmade brewed in small quantity in the German capital, the microbrewery launched its outdoor biergarten. In a building made of former shipping containers, BRLO Brwhouse (the first word means Berlin in old Slavic dialect) unveils a selection of about twenty crafted beers, to be tried for pre-dinner on the large terrace that gives on the Gleisdreieck Park. A few deck chairs add to the family setting, with a sandpit installed for young patrons. For dinner time, the restaurant boasts a menu that changes every month. Local products are being used, like cauliflower, kohlrabi, broccoli and radish. You can compose your dish as you please: vegetables are the main attraction, but you can also choose mashed potatoes, tabbouleh, meat or fish. Beer lovers and gourmet eaters will both feel satisfied.

BRLO Brwhouse
Schöneberger Straße 16
10963 Berlin

+49 (0)30 55 57 76 06

https://brlo-brwhouse.de/en/

Menu: around 25 EUR

content.title: Bespoke cocktails at Geist im Glas

introduction.small: In Berlin, Geist im Glas stands out with its intimate setting, homemade liquors and drink-making to suit your mood.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Bespoke cocktails at Geist im Glas

paragraphs.text:
The former blue-collar neighbourhood of Neukölln, sometimes called "Little Istanbul" in reference to the large Turkish community living there, has now become the place to be for Berlin's trendy youth. Among the most popular addresses, Geist im Glas is always packed. This cocktail bar owes its success to the cosy and welcoming atmosphere it gives off. The intimate setting is being enhanced by the use of soul music and red brick walls mainly lit by candlelight.
At the counter, there is no menu. To order, choose what you want to drink - in moderation, of course - by asking the bartender. Geist im Glas makes some homemade alcohols, like very fresh, lemon and basil-infused gin. Answer the mixologist's questions and he will define what cocktail best suits your taste on the spot. The following morning, you can head back there for one of the best brunches in town, offering large and creative servings in rustic wooden plates.

Geist im Glas
Lenaustraße 27
12047 Berlin

+49 (0)152 5135 3816

https://geistimglas.de/

Menu: cocktails from 6.5 EUR

content.title: Danish beer at Mikkeller

introduction.small: Taking hold in the trendy Mitte neighbourhood, Mikkeller offers brewed beers in a Scandinavian setting.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Danish beer at Mikkeller

paragraphs.text:
Considered as one of the best breweries in the world, the famous Danish franchise takes over the German capital. A stone's throw from Rosenthaler Platz, Mikkeller's minimalistic universe directly draws from the Scandinavian way of thinking. White bricks, wood everywhere, red stools, large public benches and stylish suspended lighting give this three-room beer bar a cosy feel. Hops enthusiasts gather to taste – in moderation – one of the 24 draught beers inscribed on the black board over the counter. Served in a Mikkeller branded beer mug (representing two Danish characters chatting), most are locally home brewed. A few snacks complete the tasting, like cheese and cold cuts. Whether you are a connoisseur or not, you will enjoy the wide beer selection while taking in a very serene feeling.

Mikkeller
Torstraße 102
10119 Berlin

+49 (0)176 83 14 11 03

https://www.facebook.com/mikkellerberlin/

Menu: beers from 4 EUR

content.title: Panama, a fairy tale turned restaurant

introduction.small: Located on the unmissable Potsdamer Straße in Berlin, Panama has fast become a reference for fusion food.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Panama, a fairy tale turned restaurant

paragraphs.text:
The restaurant's first influence comes from a children's book, Oh, Wie schön ist Panana (Oh, How Beautiful Panama Is). In this tale, author Horst Eckert - pen name Janosch - tells the story of a bear and a tiger looking for a paradise called "Panama". In Berlin, chef Sophia Rudolph follows the same goal, this time transposed in the world of gastronomy. Her menu, changing every season, unveils local products combined with exotic inspirations.
You will find food groups thematically listed: "raw" (Hohenlohe beef tartare), "flowers and leaves" (coconut and sesame cream eggplant), "seeds and vegetables" (pea soup, kimchi and chorizo), "fish and meat" (salt-marsh shoulder of lamb, tamarind and string beans)… On the patio or the bright and stylish indoor dining room, you will discover this sophisticated cuisine with Panamanian overtones, available for dinner only.

Panama
Potsdamer Straße 91
10785 Berlin

+49 (0)30 983 208 435

https://oh-panama.com/en/welcome/

Menu: around 37 EUR

content.title: Visit the Reichstag, the German Parliament

introduction.small: From its construction in 1880 till now, the Reichstag has always been on the forefront of history: between fire and bombs, it hasn't been spared anything.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Visit the Reichstag, the German Parliament

paragraphs.text:
10 years in the making, the Reichstag was completed in 1894 to house the National Assembly. Already subject to controversy - because it was taller than Emperor Whilhelm II's castle, the palace suffered the vagaries of history on multiple occasions. In February 1933, the infamous Reichstag fire was used as pretext by Nazis to justify repressive measures imposed on the opposition. Almost completely destroyed by World War II bombings, the monument has been rebuilt between 1961 and 1971 in simplified form. The glass cupola that overlooks the palace is a sign of its newfound modernity.
One year after German Reunification in 1990, the Reichstag building became the country's Parliament. The cupola and the façade are easy to recognize and it is now one of Berlin's most famous historical locations. You can visit the cupola's terrace, offering unobstructed views onto the whole capital. Visit is free of charge, but you may want to book it a couple of days beforehand.

Reichstag (German Parliament)
Platz der Republik 1
11011 Berlin

+49 (0)30 22 73 21 52

https://www.visitberlin.de/en/reichstag-in-berlin

content.title: Shopping among friends on the Kurfürstendamm

introduction.small: A stroll on the Kurfürstendamm, the city's most popular shopping street is a mandatory stop during your Berlin trip.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Shopping among friends on the Kurfürstendamm

paragraphs.text:
Meander on the Kurfürstendamm. Before reaching the Kaiser Wilhelm Gedächtniskirche, between Hermès, Chanel, Louis Vuitton, Cartier and Gucci shops, take a peep at Jil Sander's boutique. Art director for her own fashion house but also Prada and ready-to-wear brands like Uniqlo, she's been called the "queen of minimalism". You may give in to a man's cotton and wool button-down shirt, or a knee-high minimalist black envelope-style dress that will highlight your figure. Close to the Tauentzienstraße, you have to make another stop by the Europa-Centre, Berlin's oldest shopping mall. This high building topped with the Mercedes logo accommodates some 70 shops, the Stachelschweine cabaret theatre and the city's tourism office. A little bit further, do not miss the GALERIA Berlin Kurfürstendamm's front windows. Better known as Karstadt, it is yet another famous department store

Jil Sander
Kurfürstendamm 185
10707 Berlin
+49 (0)30 886 7020

Europa-Center
Tauentzienstraße 9-12
10789 Berlin
+49 (0)30 2649 7940
https://europa-center-berlin.de/en/

GALERIA (Karstadt) Berlin Kurfürstendamm
Kurfürstendamm 231
10719 Berlin
+49 (0)30 880 030
https://www.galeria.de/on/demandware.store/Sites-Galeria-Site/de/

content.title: The Brücke-Museum, with David Bowie and Iggy Pop in mind

introduction.small: As the only museum in the world dedicated to the Brücke movement, it houses unique collections.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Brücke-Museum, with David Bowie and Iggy Pop in mind

paragraphs.text:
A hall of fame or the Expressionist movement founded in 1967 and initiated by painter, engraver and plastic artist Karl Schmidt-Rottluff, the Brücke-Museum is located only five minutes away by foot from the Pücklerstraße bus station. Bordering on Grünewald forest, this museum offers major art by key expressionist artists of the Die Brücke movement, created in Dresde in 1905. Karl Schmidt-Rottluff himself, as well as Max Pechstein, Ernst-Ludwig Kirchner, Erich Heckel, Emil Nolde and Otto Mueller have all demonstrated how Germany in the early 20th century was leading the avant-garde on an international level.

All along the museum's clear-looking rooms, you will be dazzled by the bold colours splashing everywhere. Among the various pieces exhibited, you will find Erich Heckel's Roquairol (1917), worth the visit in itself and an inspiration source for Iggy Pop's 1977 The Idiot, coproduced and co-written by David Bowie, as well as Bowie's own Heroes (also from 1977).

Brücke-Museum
Bussardsteig 9
14195 Berlin

+49 (0)30 8390 0860

https://www.bruecke-museum.de/en/

content.title: Mövenpick Hotel, so unusual

introduction.small: In a former Siemens factory site, you'll be at the forefront to explore Berlin's tumultuous past, while contributing to saving the planet.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Mövenpick Hotel, so unusual

paragraphs.text:
Two steps away from Potsdamer Platz, one of Berlin's most touristy squares, the Mövenpick Hotel took hold in a former Siemens factory. Its 243 rooms and suites (many of which give onto a charming courtyard) display a very contemporary style with wooden furniture and glass panels in the bathrooms. High ceilings and large openings also make them brighter and more welcoming.
At night, enjoy the sauna to relax after a long day spent wandering about Berlin streets filled with history. You could then have dinner at Hof Zwei, the hotel's restaurant offering special cuisine mixing Swiss and Mediterranean flavours. You can have breakfast in the same room while enjoying the natural light that passes through the glass roof.
Golden Globe certified, the hotel commits to using green and renewable energies, recycling and offering biodegradable products in the rooms.

Mövenpick Hotel Berlin
Schöneberger Straße 3
10963 Berlin

+49 (0)30 2300 60

https://www.movenpick.com/en/europe/germany/berlin/hotel-berlin/overview/

Rooms: from 63 EUR

content.title: Mein Haus Am See, ideal headquarters

introduction.small: A bar that offers large armchairs, great atmosphere and caring staff for a low price. An idea of happiness, right?

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Mein Haus Am See, ideal headquarters

paragraphs.text:
In this typical spot of the German capital, you have your choice of setting: whether at the counter, sitting at a low table in the main room or up in the rows of seats, comfortable in plump armchairs padded with cushions. Whether for a coffee around noon, a beer after work or a last drink as the early morning sun rises, the atmosphere is at once trendy and relaxed. Displaying bookshelves at the entrance, rock graffiti in the bathroom and a dance track in the basement, this is a truly unusual spot. The establishment is completely at ease with that notion, showcasing the "not a bar, not a club - something sexier in between" slogan. At night, take a break between non-stop electro concerts to find nice snacks. Live the Berlin experience until the end of the night!

Mein Haus Am See
Brunnenstraße 197-198
10119 Berlin

+49 (0)163 555 8033

https://www.mein-haus-am-see.club/

Menu: from 5.50 EUR

content.title: Bandol sur Mer, highly energetic restaurant

introduction.small: Quite simply the best and trendiest French restaurant in Berlin.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Bandol sur Mer, highly energetic restaurant

paragraphs.text:
In the middle of the Torstraße area, Bandol sur Mer, a French restaurant whose name evokes the sun and pine trees of the Mediterranean, represents one of the finest culinary experiences in Berlin.

Offering Parisian bistro cuisine in a trendy atmosphere, this tiny restaurant can only accommodate 22 people. Reservations are therefore mandatory.

Since opening in 2008, Berliners and visitors from around the world have thronged here for classic French dishes revisited by chef Andreas Saul and served with a wide selection of French and German wines, selected by sommelier Alexander Seiser. Both men have been trained at the very best establishments of their kind.

A select kind of place, it remains charming with a large bright red sign on the street, open kitchen, and daily specials chalked on the wall. It is said that Brad Pitt is a fan of the house steak, seafood, and foie gras.

Bandol-sur-Mer
Torstraße 167
10115 Berlin

+49 30 673 02051

https://en.bandolsurmer.de

Menu: from 80 EUR

content.title: East Side Gallery, the artsiest spot

introduction.small: Visit the largest open-air gallery in the world, a must-go-to of any trip to Berlin.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: East Side Gallery, the artsiest spot

paragraphs.text:
In the Friedrichshain district, the East Side Gallery is a 1.3-km-long piece of the Berlin Wall covered with street art and frescoes. Classified in 1992 as a historical monument, it is one of the largest portions of the wall that was not destroyed in 1989. Since January 1990, 118 artists from 21 different countries have come and decorated it by brush and spray can, often with messages about the division and reunification of Germany, but more often on the themes of freedom and love. Unfortunately, the drawings degrade over time and the wall is crumbling. Near the Ostbahn of train station, 40 drawings were renovated in 2009 to celebrate the 20th anniversary of the fall of the wall. Today, the artists behind the East Side Gallery have mounted an association to raise funds, and other renovation projects are underway.

East Side Gallery
Mühlenstraße 73 (meeting point)
10243 Berlin

+49 (0)30 2130 85 222

https://eastsidegalleryberlin.de/en/

content.title: Hotel de Rome, the height of authenticity

introduction.small: A hotel rooted in the history and culture of Berlin for you to explore its most spectacular episodes.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hotel de Rome, the height of authenticity

paragraphs.text:
Close to Unter den Linden, the Opera House, and the Brandenburg Gate, this high-end hotel is housed in a 19th-century building that was the Bank of Dresden until 1945. The building has been renovated while taking its history into consideration. In that respect, the spa, sauna, and swimming pool are installed in the bank's ancient vaults, in the basement, while the Opera Suite is the former office of the prestigious institution's founder. The Hotel de Rome's 146 stylish rooms have high ceilings, oak panelling, saturated colours, and high-tech equipment. La Banca, the superb restaurant on the fifth floor, serves Italian dishes: the spaghetti al pomodoro is the best you will find in the German capital. In summer, the rooftop terrace offers panoramic views of the city.

Hotel de Rome, a Rocco Forte Hotel
Behrenstraße 37
10117 Berlin

+49 (0)30 460 6090

https://www.roccofortehotels.com/hotels-and-resorts/hotel-de-rome/

Rooms: from 252 EUR

content.title: Gorki Apartments in trendy Berlin

introduction.small: To discover Berlin off the beaten track, rent lavish apartments where one could live for one night or… forever.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Gorki Apartments in trendy Berlin

paragraphs.text:
Located in the youth centre of Berlin, Gorki Apartments is a stylish and quiet aparthotel surrounded by the city's best bars, galleries, cafés, and shops. Here, luxurious residences have names like Clara Ludwig or Pia Wilhelm, and individual doorbells and mailboxes, just like at home. In this residential building from the 19th century, the 34 independent apartments and two penthouses have fully equipped kitchens, cosy double bedrooms, and a lounge with flat-screen TV and Wi-Fi. The height of luxury can be found in the bathroom: small linen bags containing organic beauty products by Dr. Bronner's. A luxury grocery service is available on request, and Pelago Finnish bicycles are available in the courtyard. With its chic design that blends vintage and contemporary, Gorky Apartments lets you feel at home. A hearty breakfast, with hot drinks, freshly squeezed juices, and hot and cold dishes can be ordered at Café Gorki Park, on the ground floor of the building.

Gorki Apartments
Weinbergsweg 25
10119 Berlin

+49 (0)30 48 49 64 80

https://www.gorkiapartments.com/en

Apartments: from 168 EUR

content.title: Discover an abandoned airport

introduction.small: For sports, barbecues with friends or just hanging out, the former Berlin-Tempelhof airport is the new favourite place for Berliners.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Discover an abandoned airport

paragraphs.text:
After closing in 2008, the Berlin-Tempelhof International Airport's 386 hectares of land (and third largest building in the world in terms of floor area, behind the Pentagon and the presidential palace in Bucharest) was turned into a park. Larger than Central Park in New York City, it has a six-kilometre paved path for bikes, skaters, and joggers, two-and-a-half hectares for barbecues, four hectares of grass for dogs, half a hectare of shared gardens, and a huge picnic area open to everyone. At the edge of Neukölln, one of the new trendy neighbourhoods, it is a weekend meeting place for Berliners. Every element of the old airport has been put to use, right down to the red and white blocks that were used to organise traffic on the tarmac, which are now benches. The three entrances, on Columbiadamm, Tempelhofer Damm, and Oderstraße, are open from sunrise to sunset.

Berlin-Tempelhof
Tempelhofer Damm 1-7
12101 Berlin

https://www.thf-berlin.de/en/

content.title: Holocaust Memorial

introduction.small: Dedicated to the murdered Jews of Europe, this memorial offers civic, humanist and sensible awareness.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Holocaust Memorial

paragraphs.text:
Opened May 10, 2005, 60 years after the capitulation of Nazi Germany, the Holocaust Memorial, dedicated to the murdered Jews of Europe, is a stele field accessible from all sides. Located in the city centre, and free of charge, it receives more than 500,000 visitors a year. On the 19,000-sqm site, the New York architect Peter Eisenman erected 2,711 concrete blocks of different heights assembled in a checkerboard pattern. You can enter the monument through its four sides and walk among its wave-shaped structure, which is perceived differently depending on where one is located. This artistic project, long controversial, is enriched with an underground information centre of 800 sqm. In the Hall of Names, the Raum der Namen, a voice reads out the name of each of the six million victims of the Holocaust, and gives a short biography of each person. It would take 15 years to hear all their names…

Foundation Memorial to the Murdered Jews of Europe
Cora-Berliner-Straße 1
10117 Berlin

+49 (0)30 2639 430

https://www.stiftung-denkmal.de/?lang=en

content.title: Borchardt Restaurant, Berlin's VIP eatery

introduction.small: Like George Clooney, Leonardo DiCaprio, Madonna and Barack Obama before you, play the celeb in front of your Wiener Schnitzel.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Borchardt Restaurant, Berlin's VIP eatery

paragraphs.text:
Open since 1992 in the new city centre, this trendy brasserie attracts a host of celebrities of all kinds, plus their counterparts in politics, media, and show business. The golden columns, red velvet curtains, statues, mosaics, and stucco ceilings give a quaintly out-dated atmosphere to this ultra-trendy address. A true Berlin institution, Borchardt Restaurant is especially famous for its Wiener Schnitzel: served with warm potato salad, it is considered the best in town. The schnitzel always comes with delicious side dishes like grilled artichokes with red peppers, beet salad with horseradish, creamy mashed celery, or cabbage with thyme. In the daytime, take advantage of the inner courtyard's terrace, weather permitting, of course.

Borchardt Restaurant
Französische Straße 47
10117 Berlin

+49 (0)30 81 88 62 62

https://borchardt-restaurant.de/en/home-2-2/

Menu: from 40 EUR

content.title: TrabiWorld, safari in a Trabant

introduction.small: See the city at the wheel of this legendary car, for an experience “back to the future”.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: TrabiWorld, safari in a Trabant

paragraphs.text:
The Trabi-Safari allows you to explore the streets of the city and its monuments from a new perspective. Passengers follow descriptions of the places they're seeing on their car radios. If this is your first time in Berlin, opt to visit the city centre and West Berlin. The Trabi-Safari City West is 75 minutes long, during which you will learn about the history of the city and its cultural life, and the expansion of Mitte, the up-and-coming arty area. You travel down the most famous shopping street, the Ku-Damm and past the largest shopping centre in continental Europe, the KaDeWe. If you enjoyed the ride, you can throw yourself into an exploration of the Wall and its history with The Wall Ride, or explore the fascinating city to the east with the Wild East.

TrabiWorld Berlin
Zimmerstraße 97
10117 Berlin

+49 30 302 01030

www.trabi-safari.de/index.php?language=en

content.title: SO/ Berlin Das Stue, two steps away from the zoo

introduction.small: The latest fashionable spot in Berlin, a discreet place with a distinctive aesthetic sensibility to feel just like at home.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: SO/ Berlin Das Stue, two steps away from the zoo

paragraphs.text:
In the Tiergarten park, next to the Berlin Zoo, Das Stue, a Danish salon, is a sophisticated urban retreat. Set in a 1930s building, which was originally the Royal Danish Embassy in Berlin, this surprising boutique hotel provides a blessed calm amid lush greenery. Spanish designer Patricia Urquiola has given a refined and elegant look to the luxurious interiors. The 78 rooms have breath-taking views of the zoo, and animals are everywhere in the decor: a leather rhinoceros, wire monkeys, and a crocodile skull in the lobby. Choose a room on the second floor, Le Bel Etage, and sleep in the old elegant reception rooms of the embassy. In his Michelin-starred restaurant, 5-Cinco by Paco Pérez, the Catalan chef Pérez proposes pioneering Mediterranean cuisine with nods to German gastronomy. The spacious Susanne Kaufmann Spa is a great place to unwind after a long day of sightseeing, and you can also dive into the 14-metre indoor swimming pool, or relax in the Finnish sauna.

SO/ Berlin Das Stue
Drakestraße 1
10787 Berlin

+49 (0)30 3117 220

https://www.so-berlin-das-stue.com/en/

Rooms: from 227 EUR

content.title: The TV Tower at Alexanderplatz

introduction.small: Climbing to the top of this legendary tower offers incredible views of the whole city.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The TV Tower at Alexanderplatz

paragraphs.text:
For a panoramic view of the city, visit the Berliner Fernsehturm, Berlin's TV Tower, a 368-m concrete column painted white. Inaugurated in 1969, it is the highest publicly accessible building in Europe. Its panoramic viewing floors at 203 and 207 m provide a magnificent view of the city and its monuments, such as the Reichstag, the Brandenburg Gate, the Hauptbahnhof (central railway station), Museum Island, and Potsdamer Platz. Symbol of Communist East Berlin, it dominates Alexanderplatz and the avenues and blocks of flats of the Soviet era. Each year more than a million visitors from 86 countries make the climb. For the more courageous, there is a rotating restaurant in the globe on the very top of the tower, where you can have a full lunch or just a drink and a pastry.

Berliner Fernsehturm
Panoramastraße 1A
Alexanderplatz
10178 Berlin

+49 (0)30 242 3333

https://tv-turm.de/en/

content.title: The Hamburger Bahnhof-Museum für Gegenwart, for art's sake

introduction.small: The city's oldest railway station houses the wonderful Museum for Contemporary Art, very popular with Berlin's youth.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Hamburger Bahnhof-Museum für Gegenwart, for art's sake

paragraphs.text:
The Hamburger Bahnhof-Museum für Gegenwart, the old station linking the capital to Hamburg, is today home to 10,000 sqm of exhibition space dedicated exclusively to contemporary art from the 1950s to the present. Badly damaged during the Second World War, the building was converted in 1996. The historical details mixed with modern architecture provide the perfect setting for this great collection. The works of art, which come from the collection of the State Museums of Berlin and the private collection of Erich Marx, are by, among others, Andy Warhol, Cy Twombly, Robert Rauschenberg, Roy Lichtenstein, Anselm Kiefer, and Joseph Beuys. Open since 2004, the Rieck-Hallen are large exhibition areas adjoining the museum. It contains part of the Friedrich Christian Flick Collection and temporary exhibitions held here have shown the works of Bruce Nauman, Sol LeWitt, Nam June Paik, Gerhard Richter, and Sigmar Polke. The museum also houses a modern restaurant, the Sarah Wiener, which serves a very good lunch.

Hamburger Bahnhof-Museum für Gegenwart
Invalidenstraße 50-51
10557 Berlin

+49 (0)30 266 42 42 42

https://www.smb.museum/en/museums-institutions/hamburger-bahnhof/home.html

content.title: Try a currywurst to play the foodie tourist

introduction.small: Curry 36 is the address where hipsters and millenials throng to test the Berlin specialty.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Try a currywurst to play the foodie tourist

paragraphs.text:
The currywurst, a curry pork sausage, is a Berlin specialty now enjoyed all over Germany. Legend has it that it was invented in 1949, just after the Second World War, in the Charlottenburg district, and was an immediate runaway success with the US military stationed there. Today, about 70 million are sold annually. Boiled or fried, it is traditionally cut into small pieces, doused in a sauce consisting of ketchup or tomato paste, Worcestershire sauce, and curry powder, and served in a brötchen (roll) or on a small tray with chips. You will find them sold at stands almost everywhere throughout the city and in the many Stehcafés (stand-up coffee kiosks), but rather try one at Curry 36, in Kreuzberg. For more than 30 years, the emblematic 36 Mehringdamm address has been known as the best currywurst stand in all of Germany. The wait can be long but worth it for the taste.

Curry 36
Mehringdamm 36
10961 Berlin

+49 (0)30 25 17 368 +49 (0)30 25 80 08 830

https://curry36.de/de/

content.title: The Michelberger Hotel, a waking dream

introduction.small: A wacky place, not to be missed if you want to experience alternative Berlin.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Michelberger Hotel, a waking dream

paragraphs.text:
Conceived by designer Werner Aisslinger, the Michelberger is a very cool-looking converted factory in the heart of Berlin's lively Friedrichshain district. The lobby has giant sofas, the café has live music jams every night, with free access to musical instruments, and the Whisky Room is filled with antique furniture from the Mauerpark flea market. The 119 rooms for two, three, or eight people are different but all very bright, with high ceilings. The restaurant has mismatched chairs and tiles and serves gargantuan breakfasts prepared with fresh, local ingredients, served on kitchen tables. The bar is open all day and the house cocktails are sublime. In summer, patrons come to sunbathe on deckchairs, hang out in the Biergarten, and dine around the large barbecue. The East Side Gallery is a five-minute walk and the Kreuzberg district a mere ten.

The Michelberger Hotel
Warschauer Str. 39-40
10243 Berlin

+49 (0)30 29 77 85 90

https://www.michelbergerhotel.com/en/

Rooms: from 93 EUR

content.title: Sofitel Berlin Kurfürstendamm, the French touch

introduction.small: Formerly known as Hotel Concorde, it combines opulence, design, and the French art of living.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Sofitel Berlin Kurfürstendamm, the French touch

paragraphs.text:
Located just off the Kurfürstendamm, the Champs-Élysées of Berlin, Sofitel Berlin Kurfürstendamm is close to shopping centres, bars, restaurants, and cafés. In an Art Deco building designed by the famous Berlin architect Jan Kleihues, the former Hotel Concorde Berlin features 311 rooms, including 44 suites, a large ballroom, and meeting rooms decorated with artworks.

This French-style five-star luxury is perfectly reflected in each room. Inspired by artist Junior Toscanelli, who was fond of warm colours, they make heavy use of wood panelling, with soft cushions under the windows for comfortably taking in the view. A full breakfast is served each morning in the Saint Germain restaurant, while the Brasserie Le Faubourg, with its large windows and street terrace, offers refined French cuisine in the evenings. The cocktail bar, the Lutece, offers the widest range of vodkas in town.

Sofitel Berlin Kurfürstendamm
Augsburger Straße 41
10789 Berlin

+49 (0)30 800 9990

https://sofitel.accor.com/hotel/9387/index.en.shtml

Rooms: from 114 EUR

content.title: Revitalise on Museum Island

introduction.small: In the heart of the city, Museum Island is a fascinating place for a promenade, at once friendly and trendy.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Revitalise on Museum Island

paragraphs.text:
Recognised as a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1999, Museum Island is home to five world-famous museums: the Pergamon Museum (Pergamonmuseum) reveals ancient artefacts and offers an area dedicated to Islamic art; the Old Museum (Altes Museum) shelters exceptional treasures from the Greek, Roman and Etruscan periods; the National Gallery (Alte Nationalgalerie) exhibits masterpieces of Impressionist and Realist paintings; the Bode Museum (formerly the Kaiser-Friedrich-Museum) will please sculpture, Byzantine art and medal lovers; finally, the New Museum (Neues Museum) showcases cultural history around the globe from the Stone age to the Middle Ages.

In the early 19th century, art and culture began to bloom in this former residential area with the construction of the Altes Museum, which houses the royal collection of ancient art. The four other museums were built between 1824 and 1930. Illustrating the evolution of modern museum design, the collections span 6,000 years of art history, from the bust of Nefertiti to the Pergamon Altar. In the city centre, the island is one of Berlin's main attractions, and a great place for a walk.

Museumsinsel Berlin
Am Lustgarten
10117 Berlin

https://www.smb.museum/en/home/

content.title: Kimchi Princess, Korean yet passionately Berlin

introduction.small: What better way to kick off the night at this cosmopolitan Korean restaurant with sizzling barbecues.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Kimchi Princess, Korean yet passionately Berlin

paragraphs.text:
Located right next to the metro station Görlitzer Bahnhof and its sister restaurants Angry Chicken and Soju Bar, Kimchi Princess is the perfect place to start the evening. In a large room, with red walls lit by red neon lights, the wooden tables can accommodate large dinner parties or intimate tastings. The place takes its name from the Korean fermented cabbage condiment, the house specialty here, perfectly fermented and with a good dose of spice. But the real star is the Korean BBQ, which sits at the centre of each table. You can choose beef, octopus, classic pork bulgogi, vegetables or 'The Fantastic Entrecote', in ultra-thin slices. For starters, let yourself be tempted by steamed dishes, dumplings, and pancakes. Cosmopolitan, lively and always welcoming, Kimchi Princess is a real Berlin experience.

Kimchi Princess
Skalitzer Str. 36
10999 Berlin

+49 (0)163 458 0203

www.kimchiprincess.com

Menu: around 30 EUR

content.title: A cruise on the River Spree, the height of romanticism

introduction.small: Whisk away and discover the city centre of Berlin from a different angle.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: A cruise on the River Spree, the height of romanticism

paragraphs.text:
Berlin has more waterways than Venice, and a boat tour is a great way to see the city. Gardens, modern and historical buildings, monuments, and even shopping streets take on another dimension when seen from the water. Embark on a riverboat or a steamboat and navigate to the city centre, passing under famous bridges such as the Oberbaumbrücke and Schlossbrücke, and gliding past monuments like the Bellevue Palace, the Berlin Cathedral, and Museum Island. The cruise takes you to the Saint-Nicolas district, the oldest part of the city, where you will see modern architecture like the Haus der Kulturen der Welt and Norman Foster's dome on the renovated Reichstag. You can also explore the hipster scene in East Berlin or cruise on Lake Wannsee and the Havel River to learn more about the history of the region.

Reederei Riedel
+49 (0)30 62 93 31 94
https://reederei-riedel.de/en/

Stern & Kreisschiffahrt
+49 (0)30 53 63 600
https://www.sternundkreis.de/en/Startseite/E1001.htm?_sm_au_=iHVMrWLj86pDnqVqjkM0vKQ6c702G

BWSG Berliner Wassersport und Service GmbH
+49 (0)30 65 13 415
https://www.bwsg-berlin.de/en/

content.title: Family picnic at Großer Tiergarten

introduction.small: Stroll through the oldest park in the city, and enjoy its 32 km of trails for a natural experience in the heart of the metropolis.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Family picnic at Großer Tiergarten

paragraphs.text:
A former game reserve, the Großer Tiergarten ('animal garden') is home to many wild animals. So many, in fact, that the municipality has even mandated 35 urban hunters to fight against the proliferation of game. Located in the Berlin-Tiergarten district, this is the second largest park in the city. Berliners like to come here for walks, family picnics, bike tours, games of football, Sunday barbecues, or to sit at the lakeside café. Its 210 hectares contain rolling lawns, small ponds, undergrowth, large avenues, and monuments, such as the Bellevue Palace and the Reichstag. In the southeast, near Potsdamer Platz, is a large playground for children and, in winter, you can even skate on the frozen ponds like an Olympic medallist.

Großer Tiergarten
Straße des 17. Juni 31
10785 Berlin

https://www.visitberlin.de/en/tiergarten

content.title: Grill Royal for meat, but not only…

introduction.small: A real high-end steakhouse, for food and fresh produce lovers.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Grill Royal for meat, but not only…

paragraphs.text:
Overlooking the River Spree, the Grill is the restaurant of the stars in Berlin. Leonardo DiCaprio, Scarlett Johansson and Karl Lagerfeld have dined here. Dark flooring, plush banquettes, large windows, soft lighting, and sculptures give it a chic and cosy feel. There's a lovely terrace on the river and a smoking lounge with vintage photos on the walls. The owners, Boris Radczun and art collector Stefan Landwehr, have created the luxury steakhouse of their dreams. Wagyu beef from Australia, filet mignon, and steaks are the specialties of the house. There's also shrimp, lobster, sea bream, and vegetarian dishes, all made with healthy and super fresh produce. The food is grilled right in front of you and elegantly served with great ceremony. The Champagne list is the best in the German capital.

Grill Royal
Friedrichstraße 105b
10117 Berlin

+49 30 28879288

https://grillroyal.com/en/

Menu: around 60 EUR

content.title: Cookies Cream, industrial style and super fresh produce

introduction.small: The 100% vegetarian and seriously quirky Berlin restaurant that should not be missed.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Cookies Cream, industrial style and super fresh produce

paragraphs.text:
Finding this trendy vegetarian restaurant is a challenge. To enter Cookies Cream, you have to go through the service entrance of the Westin Grand Berlin and press an unmarked buzzer. Upstairs, after going in the back door, you land in an industrial space with raw concrete walls, an open kitchen, and tables draped in linen where flavourful vegetarian dishes are being served. In this abandoned loft atmosphere, all very Berlin, the ingredients are always ultra-fresh and seasonal, and the menu changes every week. Stephan Hentschel, the chef, has a number of signature dishes, including parmesan dumplings, fried egg yolks with lentils, and wild herb salad. The staff is laid-back and the crowd very friendly, mainly clubbers from the famous Cookie just downstairs, financial types in suits, and lovers on holiday. Hidden but very famous, it is advisable to book one of the 15 tables ahead of time.

Cookies Cream
Behrenstraße 55
10117 Berlin

+49 (0)30 680 730 448

https://cookiescream.com

Menu: around 30 EUR

content.title: CLIMATE AND WEATHER IN Berlin
content.introduction: Berlin has a semi-continental climate. The German capital experiences fairly cold and relatively dry winters. Summers are usually warm, with occasional thunderstorms.

content.title: Currency and Exchange Rates
content.description: The currency used in Germany is the Euro (EUR).
content.validity: The above exchange rate is given for information because is variable.

airports.title: Berlin-Brandenburg Willy-Brandt International Airport
airports.description:
The Berlin-Brandenburg Willy-Brandt International Airport is located about 28 kilometres (17 miles) south of the city centre. It opened on October 31st, 2020.
  • Three terminals
    • Terminal 1 (Air France)
    • Terminal 2
    • Terminal 5

Please note that terminal 5 is located on the site of the former Schönefeld airport. It is therefore not accessible by foot from terminals 1 and 2. To do so, please use the S9 and S45 suburban trains (travel time of about 8 minutes).

Getting from the airport to Berlin and back:
  • By car
    • Accessible via the six-lane A113 (Flughafen Berlin Brandenburg exit), with a travel time of about 45 minutes.
    • More than 10,000 parking spaces are available:
      • P1 and P3 parking facilities located near Terminal 1, easy to access by foot. EUR 3 for 1 hour, then EUR 3 per extra hour, or EUR 25 for 1 day and EUR 39 for 2 days.
      • P7 and P8 parking facilities located near terminal 2. EUR 3 for 1 hour, then EUR 3 per extra hour.
      • P51, P52, P54 and P56 parking facilities located near Terminal 5. Several charging stations for electric cars are available there. EUR 3 for 1 hour, then between EUR 3 and EUR 6 per extra hour.
      • Several car rental companies have counters at the airport's terminals.

Whether by suburban train (S-Bahn) or bus, many modes of public transportation connect the airport with the city centre of Berlin. EUR 3.60 for a one-way ticket.

Please note that the Berlin WelcomeCard (EUR 23 for 48 hours and EUR 33 for 72 hours) grants you free transportation in all public transports. For further information, please visit https://www.visitberlin.de/en/berlin-welcome-card.
  • By train
    • S-Bahn: the S9 and S45 suburban trains connect the airport with the city centre. Trains leave every 20 minutes and make a stop at the “Terminal 5” station.
    • Airport Express: this train takes you to the Berlin central station (Hauptbahnhof) in 30 minutes. It runs several times every hour.
  • By bus
    • Several bus lines connect the airport with the city centre. Lines 163, 164 and 171 run about every 20 minutes. From midnight to 4:30 a.m., night buses take over (N7 buses every 30 min, N7X every 15 minutes, N36 every hour, and N60 every 30 minutes).
    • Express bus lines X7 (every 5 minutes), X71 (every 20 minutes) and BER1 (every hour) are operated from 4:30 a.m. to midnight, with a travel time of 45 to 50 minutes. Tickets can be purchased from the driver on board.
  • By taxi
    • Taxis are available at the ranks from terminals T1, T2 and T5, city bound. Make sure you use an official taxi. The trip to central Berlin takes about 45 minutes and costs around EUR 50.
  • Services: shops, bars and restaurants, free Internet access (Wi-Fi) available in the airport.
  • Telephone: +49 (0)30 6091 6091 0
  • Website: https://ber.berlin-airport.de/en.html

transportation.title: GETTING AROUND Berlin
transportation.description: Berlin is a very easy city to get around. Its public transport options provide nearly complete coverage of the city, by night as well as by day. The S-Bahn, U-Bahn and trams run through the night on Friday and Saturday and the eves of public holidays. In addition, the system uses integrated tickets and passes, valid for all modes of transport.

touristInformation.title: Visitor information
touristInformation.description: Upon your arrival in Berlin, you can get in touch with local tourism professionals for further information and to help organize your stay.

information.title: Berlin Tourismus & Kongress
information.description:
Offers practical information and many useful recommendations (accommodation, restaurants, public transport, festivals, cultural events, etc.).

  • Address: Hauptbahnhof (Europaplatz entrance), 10557 Berlin
  • Telephone: +49 (0)30 25 00 23 33
  • Website: https://www.visitberlin.de/en

information.title: Berlin Tourist Info centres
information.description:
Apart from the main tourist information centre at Berlin Hauptbahnhof, the city's tourism authority also operates additional Berlin Tourist Info centres at the following locations:

  • Tegel Airport: Terminal A, near Gate 1 (open daily 8 a.m. to 9 p.m.)
  • Brandenburg Gate: Pariser Platx, südliches Torhaus (open daily 9:30 a.m. to 7 p.m. April–October and 9:30 a.m. to 6 p.m. November–March)
  • Europa Center: Tauentzienstraße 9 (Erdgeschoss, open 10 a.m. to 8 p.m. Monday to Saturday)
  • TV Tower: Panoramastraße 1a (open daily 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. April–October and 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. November–March)
  • Rankestraße: Kurfürstendamm 1 (open daily 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. April–October and 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. November–March)

information.title: Further information available online for visitors to Germany
information.description:
The official website maintained by Deutsche Zentrale für Tourismus (DZT), the German national tourist board, provides a wealth of information on Berlin.

Website: https://www.germany.travel/en/index.html

medical.title: Medical information
medical.description:
In order to travel in the best conditions and for your health and safety, we invite you to check all information regarding preventive measures and best practices to be respected, available on the official website of the French Ministry of Foreign Affairs: https://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/en/country-files/

Your comfort, well-being and health are at the heart of Air France's concerns, and we want to help you prepare for your trip in the best way possible. Find out more about the measures taken to ensure safe travelling on our website: https://www.airfrance.fr/FR/en/common/page_flottante/information/coronavirus.htm#notre-engagement-sanitaire

See your doctor before you travel. It is also recommended to take out insurance covering medical expenses and repatriation before your trip. Berlin counts several hospitals and medical institutions, as well as quality medical practitioners and health specialists.

information.title: Vaccinations
information.description:
There are no vaccination requirements for visitors to Germany.
For more information, contact Air France's international vaccination centre:

  • Address: 38 quai de Jemmapes, 75010 Paris
  • Website: https://www.vaccinations-airfrance.fr
  • Telephone: +33 (0)1 43 17 22 00
  • To make a vaccination appointment:
    • online (click here)
    • call the centre at +33 (0)1 43 17 22 00

information.title: Water
information.description: Tap water is safe to drink in Berlin.

essentialPhrases.title: Essential phrases
essentialPhrases.introduction: Here are a few basic German phrases that will make your stay in Berlin a little easier:
phrases: Hello / Good morning / Good afternoon: Guten Morgen (morning) / Guten Tag (during the day)
Could you repeat?: Können Sie bitte wiederholen?
What time is it?: Wie spät ist es?
How much is (…)?: Wie viel kostet es?
Where can I find (…)?: Wo kann ich (…) finden?
Where can I buy (…)?: Wo kann ich (…) kaufen?

localCalendar.title: FESTIVALS, HOLIDAYS AND OTHER ANNUAL EVENTS IN Berlin
localCalendar.description: There are a number of festivals, holidays and other events celebrated in Berlin each year. The main ones are listed below.

events.title: January 1: New Year's Day (Neujahrstag) (national holiday)
events.description: From 4 a.m. to 6 p.m. on Good Friday, it is forbidden to dance (“tanzverbot“) on the streets of Berlin, as in the other cities around the country. It is a sign of respect for the faithful who pay tribute to the ordeal of Christ.

events.title: March or April: Easter Monday (Ostermontag) (national holiday)
events.description: In Berlin, parents hide candy and Easter eggs painted in bold colours, which kids merrily go on the hunt for.

events.title: May 1: Labour Day (Tag der Arbeit) (national holiday)
events.description: On the first of May, it is customary to offer a sprig of lily-of-the-valley to close ones. Many vendors occupy the pavement on that occasion!

events.title: Second week in August: International dance festival (Tanz Im August) (local event)
events.description: This three-week festival is a celebration of modern dance, showcasing the latest trends in choreography, in a series of performances at various venues across the city featuring companies and artists from all over the world. The programme also includes workshops and lectures by both dancers and critics.

events.title: October 3: German Unity Day (Tag der Deutschen Einheit) (national holiday)
events.description: Commemorates the anniversary of Germany's reunification in 1990. Celebrations in Berlin include a huge street party at the Brandenburg Gate, plus concerts and other stage performances.

events.title: First week in November: JazzFest Berlin (local event)
events.description: Held every year since 1964, this four-day jazz festival attracts many big names for a programme of performances at the Haus der Berliner Festspiele and several other venues in the city.

events.title: November 11: Saint Martin's Day (local event)
events.description: In Berlin, Saint Martin's feast day is celebrated with a parade through the city's streets by children carrying lanterns they have usually made themselves and singing songs known as Lanternlieder.

events.title: Late November to Mid-January: Christmas market (local)
events.description: Berlin welcomes almost 70 Christmas markets. With its glassblowers dazzling visitors, the Gendarmenmarkt is steeped in history. The markets in the old town of Spandau and the Opernpalais are not to be missed!

administrativeProcedures.title: Entry requirements for Germany
administrativeProcedures.description:
As a French citizen, you do not need to obtain a visa if you will be staying in Germany for less than three months. For stays longer than three months, you will need to apply for a residence permit (Aufenthaltserlaubnis) from the Immigration Office (Ausländeramt). You will need to provide proof of sufficient financial resources to fund your proposed stay and proof of accommodation in Germany (Wohnungsbescheinigung). You will also need to be in possession of a valid national identity card or passport.

To enjoy peace of mind during your stay in Berlin and Germany, be sure to check with the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in your home country for the latest travel information and recommendations. Comprehensive information that may be helpful for international visitors is also provided on the Germany page of the U.S. State Department's travel Website: view information for travellers to Germany.

goodToKnow.title: Good to know

administration.title: GOVERNMENT OFFICES
administration.openingHours: Usually open Monday to Thursday from 8 a.m. to 5 p.m. and Friday from 8 a.m. to 2 p.m.

banks.title: BANKS
banks.openingHours: Usually open Monday to Friday from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m.

goodToKnow.daylightSavingTime:
Start of daylight saving time: last Sunday in March
End of daylight saving time: last Sunday in October
goodToKnow.tips:
Tipping
In Berlin like elsewhere in Germany, tipping is not expected. In principle, the service charge is included in the bill. But if you are particularly pleased with the service, you may certainly round up the bill or leave a few extra euros on the table.
